subject: Change command for shell
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-31 21:32:18.000000000', 'message': 'Change command for shell

The nspawn container destory command uses a pipe which is not allowed in
the command module. To correct this the shell module is used.

Change-Id: I7dacedfb62e9fd70d7b7c3130ac5af3d05711024
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Change command for shell

The nspawn container destory command uses a pipe which is not allowed in
the command module. To correct this the shell module is used.

Change-Id: I7dacedfb62e9fd70d7b7c3130ac5af3d05711024
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Make providers use auth_url for authentication
messages:
[{'account_id': 27766, 'date': '2018-08-03 09:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-08-04 17:01:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Correct approach is to land the patch on master [1], then cherry-pick (with -x) to stable branches. That way all branches share the same Change-Id, and "-x" helps trace the lineage.

Unfortunately, I think you will need to abandon all of your stable/queens patches, as they all have their own Change-Id that does not match the Change-Id of the corresponding patches on master.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/588497'}, {'account_id': 27766, 'date': '2018-08-04 18:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Alan, thanks for your review! Well, I actually intended to use the way you described. However, as the changed value is "www_authenticate_uri" on master and "auth_uri" on stable/queens, I would need to adapt every single changed line when cherry-picking, so actually create a commit that has not a single line in common with the source where it was cherry-picked from. As this felt, well, not like what a cherry-pick is intended for, I created a new commit here.

Having that said, do you still propose to create the commits on stable/queens with cherry-picking? If so, would it be enough to edit the commit message accordingly (changing Change-Id and adding the cherry-pick hint) so that I do not have to abandon and recreate everything on stable/queens?'}, {'account_id': 21129, 'date': '2018-08-04 19:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, I've also had backports where every line changed, but I think this still falls in the category of "cherry pick with conflict resolution."

Full disclosure: I am not a core reviewer for these puppet modules, so one approach you might take is to wait for a core to chime in. Maybe they're OK with your current approach.

Bear in mind, if you edit the Change-Id then gerrit will still assign a new review number. This is because gerrit tracks things by Change-Id and branch. This means you'll still need to abandon the stable/queens reviews, but that's easy to do.'}, {'account_id': 27766, 'date': '2018-08-06 09:49:22.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoned in favor of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/589093/ adhering to cherry pick convention.'}]

[{'created': '2017-04-27 11:41:02.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Implement search across all pages of list views

Change-Id: I1f0f755a3a6900c69d4e9f89239528e54adcd63c
Implements-blueprint: mistral-dashboard-search-across-pages
'}, {'created': '2017-04-27 14:04:17.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Implement search across all pages of list views

Change-Id: I1f0f755a3a6900c69d4e9f89239528e54adcd63c
Implements-blueprint: mistral-dashboard-search-across-pages
'}, {'created': '2017-07-14 12:16:01.000000000', 'message': 'Implement search across all pages of list views

commit_message:
Implement search across all pages of list views

Currently, search works only within one page. We need to implement
search functionality so that it works across all pages.

Change-Id: I1f0f755a3a6900c69d4e9f89239528e54adcd63c
Partial-implements: blueprint mistral-dashboard-search-across-pages

A recent feature has been added[1], allowing users to specify
trusted certificates (e.g. as barbican secret ids). The idea is
to ensure that the certificates used to sign the glance image
and validate it are actually trusted by the user.

In order to enable this feature within our driver, all we have to
do is pass the trusted certificate ids (stored as instance object
attribute) to the method that fetches glance images.

Marking this as WIP as I haven't tested it yet.

commit_message:
Enable trusted certificates support

A recent feature has been added, allowing users to specify
trusted certificates (e.g. as barbican secret ids). The idea is
to ensure that the certificates used to sign and validate the
glance image are actually trusted by the user.

In order to enable this feature within our driver, all we have to
do is pass the trusted certificate ids (stored as an instance
object attribute) to the method that fetches glance images.

Blueprint: nova-validate-certificates

Change-Id: Ic28f2b3ecf4ca92dcb7e9643c6e0d207d40b5287

Recently, a new pep8 rule (H903) was introduced which checks for Windows
style endings. Because of this, Zuul is failing the pep8 job.

The files were converting using dos2unix.

Change-Id: I7ea5bf692ca19895046cb0803ea9c833b19eafc7
'}]
commit_message:
trivial: Changes files Windows style line ending to Unix style

Recently, a new pep8 rule (H903) was introduced which checks for Windows
style endings. Because of this, Zuul is failing the pep8 job.

The files were converting using dos2unix.

Change-Id: I7ea5bf692ca19895046cb0803ea9c833b19eafc7

messages:
[{'account_id': 28647, 'date': '2018-07-11 11:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-07-11 11:32:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-07-11 14:07:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add doc about to delete ~/.quickstart directory before re-running quickstart.sh

Deploy will fail if reusing ~/.quickstart directory. It can be automatically deleted
running the quickstart.sh script using the -X flag

Change-Id: I0e33c5d12d83d1f1916e8fbf836005cfc39f5da0
Implements: bug
Closes-Bug: #1742149

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 5558, 'name': 'Winson Chan', 'email': 'wcchan@stackstorm.com', 'username': 'winson-c-chan'}, {'_account_id': 6732, 'name': 'Lingxian Kong', 'email': 'anlin.kong@gmail.com', 'username': 'kong'}, {'_account_id': 8731, 'name': 'Renat Akhmerov', 'email': 'renat.akhmerov@gmail.com', 'username': 'rakhmerov'}, {'_account_id': 9408, 'name': 'Michal Gershenzon', 'email': 'michal.gershenzon@gmail.com', 'username': 'Mgershen'}, {'_account_id': 9432, 'name': 'Dmitri Zimine', 'email': 'dz@stackstorm.com', 'username': 'dzimine'}, {'_account_id': 9712, 'name': 'Dougal Matthews', 'email': 'dougal.matthews@canonical.com', 'username': 'dougal'}, {'_account_id': 18238, 'name': 'Hardik Parekh', 'email': 'hardik.parekh047@gmail.com', 'username': 'hparekh'}, {'_account_id': 19206, 'name': 'Dawid Deja', 'email': 'dawdej@gmail.com', 'username': 'ddeja'}, {'_account_id': 20863, 'name': 'Sharat Sharma', 'email': 's.sharatsharma2@gmail.com', 'username': 'sharat.sharma'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-10-10 12:19:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-10 12:27:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/67/384467/1/check/gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial/a4bf5f6//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 34s
- gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/67/384467/1/check/gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/5c2c055/ : SUCCESS in 2m 14s'}, {'account_id': 18238, 'date': '2016-10-12 08:40:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Also what will be the status of workflow when it is waiting for preconditions ?

Also there is alternate way to implement this. We support mistral action packs. So, we can create some ad-hoc actions to pause/cancel/run  workflow. Such actions can be use in tasks also so workflow can be put on pause state in between (Not only when workflow is started) if some workflow is not started(or whatever condition). Thoughts ?'}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-10-14 13:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

> Also what will be the status of workflow when it is waiting for
 > preconditions ?

I imagine it as "paused", but maybe we need to add next state.

 > Also there is alternate way to implement this. We support mistral
 > action packs. So, we can create some ad-hoc actions to
 > pause/cancel/run  workflow. Such actions can be use in tasks also
 > so workflow can be put on pause state in between (Not only when
 > workflow is started) if some workflow is not started(or whatever
 > condition). Thoughts ?

Oh, I didn't thought of using ad-hoc actions for implementing this, but it may be a better idea. I would like to see others opinions.'}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-10-14 13:33:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-14 13:37:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/67/384467/2/check/gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial/5d2644c//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 29s
- gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/67/384467/2/check/gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/cf8c29e/ : SUCCESS in 2m 02s'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2016-10-18 09:51:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

and I was wondering if this functionality should be within mistral or we should leave it to higher-level applications. If we all agree that it's better to have it, I prefer implement this feature the way similar to Nova server group(we could call it workflow group), mistral could provide api to create workflow group and relationship among workflows in it."}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-10-18 13:45:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I'm open to any other ideas (such as workflow-groups), but I think this solution gives more flexibility of how given workflows should interact with each other. About leaving it to another app, that would also be OK from my point of view, but I can't think of such application."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2016-10-18 21:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I'd like other people who are also interested in this feature take a look"}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2016-11-15 12:32:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

+1 because I do like some of the ideas and I could see them being useful.
-1 because I think there is too much in this spec.

I'd +2 a more limited version of the spec that focused on the preconditions more"}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-16 11:03:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

Dougal, thanks for the review.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2016-11-16 11:07:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-20 16:50:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Dawid,

Can you please explain why do we need preconditions?

I mean, we already can add conditions to decide whether to call a task or not (each item in on-success, on-error and on-complete can have a condition).

It seems to me the same use cases can be achieved with mechanizes we have today, by simply adding some more support for functions and executions query.

Instead of putting some yaql expression in a precondition we can add a std.noop task to that workflow that will run first, publish the result of the expression evaluation, and all the tasks that once where the first to run will move to the std.noop task on-success section with a condition that the published value is true (I can add an example if needed).

Is it a usability thing? What am I missing?'}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-21 11:35:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Michal,

Yes, we can use std.noop action and inside it have some yaql that can check for required preconditions. But it doesn't solve another use case, which is:"}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-21 11:36:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As a user, I want to be able to automatically stop some other workflow(s)
when starting my workflow.

As far as I know, we cannot do it right now in mistral.'}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-21 12:45:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> As a user, I want to be able to automatically stop some other
 > workflow(s)
 > when starting my workflow.
 > 
 > As far as I know, we cannot do it right now in mistral.

Well, we have an action to delete mistral execution "mistral.executions_delete". To support such a case we can make the first task a workflow instead of std.noop, and in the workflow we can list all running executions created from the relevant workflow(*) and then delete all of them.

When you say "stop some other workflow", do you mean delete the execution or something else?

That in mind, I saw a review that wants to block deleting running executions. It might conflict with your goal: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/399379/


(*) we might need write some new code for this to work.'}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-21 13:22:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, sorry, I wanted to copy-paste another use case. This one is kind of controversial and I'm not sure if it's needed to be implemented.

Here's the use case I was originally wanted to paste:

* As a user, I want to automatically set my workflow into error state if some
other workflow(s) is running.

I gave an example of situation when it may be needed and I also think that this behavior cannot be achieve right now in mistral using existing workflow/task/action properties."}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-21 13:38:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

let me see if I understand. 1- we can set a workflow execution to error state. 2- all that is missing is getting the information on should we fail or not (e.g fail if something else already running)?


simple workflow that fails:

---
version: '2.0'

fail_wf:
  type: direct
  tasks:
    noop_and_fail_when_condition:
      action: std.noop
      on-success:
        - fail: <% true %>"}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-21 14:02:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> let me see if I understand. 1- we can set a workflow execution to
 > error state. 2- all that is missing is getting the information on
 > should we fail or not (e.g fail if something else already running)?
 > 
 > 
 > simple workflow that fails:
 > 
 > ---
 > version: '2.0'
 > 
 > fail_wf:
 > type: direct
 > tasks:
 > noop_and_fail_when_condition:
 > action: std.noop
 > on-success:
 > - fail: <% true %>

Exactly - we are missing the ability to tell if another workflow with given input is already running (like in example from lines 69-75)"}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-21 15:05:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I see, and I think I have an alternative. We can add a new yaql/jinja function called executions and have different arguments for querying (I just added a spec to do something like this for tasks: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394194/).

It will probably be faster, since there is no need to change anything in the parser, just add a new function in expression_utils.

---
version: '2.0'
fail_if_already_running:
  type: direct
  tasks:
    noop_and_fail_when_already_runnning:
      action: std.noop
      on-success:
        - fail: <% executions(null, null, RUNNING, 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426655440000) != [] %>"}, {'account_id': 19206, 'date': '2016-11-22 10:15:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

That's the interesting idea. It may works. But I see one problematic area. I'd like to be able to fail workflow execution in case some other wf is running, but without knowing the execution id. Just based on the workflow_spec name/id and input parameters. Do you think it may be possible using the workflow YAQL function?"}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-22 12:26:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

yes, it is possible. I'm going to push the tasks function soon, and I can update here when I do.

the only thing is that I am not sure if passing keywork arguments is possible. possitional arguments work fine."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2016-11-23 05:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

"workflow execution policy" seems like a more appropriate terms for the concept here. Some of the use cases here may be valid (set to WF execution to cancelled or postponed schedule if another instance is running).  However, this becomes really hard to debug if implementation goes wrong. I prefer to keep the WF DSL purely for WF execution and have these "preconditions" to be implemented separate from the main WF DSL, especially if the conditions involve another WF definitions/executions. Also, I prefer an abstraction where some of these are extended by users as plugins which they develop/manage on their own and not necessary as part of the core mistral WF engine. There also need to be good trace that is query-able by the user when these conditions cause something to happen.'}, {'account_id': 9432, 'date': '2016-11-23 17:15:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I very much agree with Lingxiang here: 
> and I was wondering if this functionality should be within mistral or we should leave it to higher-level applications.

I saw it both way in the past. Mixing the two abstractions  - workflow, and what triggers workflow (on which condition) - leads to a clutter. On user experience: you will have N triggers and M preconditions to the workflow on day 1; on day 2 you change some, remove others and add more preconditions without changing the workflows, yet you'll need to touch the workflow defintion file. A common case is conditions is mostly the same and differs only slightly - will lead to massive copy-paste across workflows, while smart separate trigger engine can serve a selector. On architecture, instead of proper separation of concern all functionality comes to the same service.

Again this approach had been done in the past, it is not "impossible", it is just very suboptimal.

This is the reason we have triggers, rules, and workflows in StackStorm as three separate concepts, using Mistral is a workflow service, which it is.

If workflow service is not what you need, I would look for higher level application or custom implementation (of pre-conditions, in this case), rather than bloating the workflow service to things that don't belong.'}, {'account_id': 9408, 'date': '2016-11-23 17:36:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

in case someone is interested, this is what I've been working on:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/401360"}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2016-11-30 10:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2016-11-30 10:47:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So, my opinion after reviewing the spec:
* We need to start with something much simpler for now (like having a precondition as a YAQL/JINJA expression)
* If we want to provide reliable checks it must be done inside Mistral for the reasons I mentioned in the comments. These checks can be done atomically outside of Mistral only if Mistral is used by one client.

After something simple is done we can declare it as "experimental" till it's well tested, discussed etc. and the DSL is established.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2016-11-30 20:13:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Renat, If you decide to move forward within Mistral, I recommend renaming this to policies and separating this from the main WF DSL. Over time, a policy can definitely be evolved into affecting more than one workflows and it doesn't make sense to have the specs inside a single WF definition. The policy needs to be defined outside of any single WF defintion."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2016-11-30 20:14:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

And if this feature is going to be experimental, I definitely don't want it in the main WF DSL."}, {'account_id': 20863, 'date': '2017-03-17 10:42:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2017-07-04 08:37:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-01-22 10:29:09.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Andras Kovi with the following votes:

* Code-Review-1 by Andras Kovi <akovi@nokia.com>
'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-08-06 09:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning this patch per the Mistral Patch Abandonment guidelines
(https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/mistral-specs/specs/policy/patch-abandonment.html).
If you wish to have this restored and cannot do so yourself, please reach
out via #openstack-mistral on freenode or the OpenStack Dev mailing list.'}]

commit_message:
Workflow preconditions

We need to be able to define preconditions so that it can be started only
if all configured preconditions are met. It would give ability to wait for
another workflow till it ends, only start workflow if another workflow is
running or even pause/cancel another workflow as a precondition.

Change-Id: I43dc9769523ee73c87c3b3c0ff7a6e5c8ff45c43

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-10-06 08:43:24.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce customisable user_context beside openstack related MistralContext

It would be very nice if custom actions could access to custom runtime execution context.
In some cases existing env is a good choice but sometimes if every execution needs
different context/env it could be a nightmare to manage env per execution or pass these
parameters down to each sub-workflow. Cloud authentication related context (MistralContext)
already addressed this issue, but it is not flexible enough.

Later may we need separate cloud credential from user_context.

Missing from current implementation:
- yaql function to reach user_context explicitly.

Change-Id: I517d6eb24b15dadb6ca402076a026e6abfbda637
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce customisable user_context beside openstack related MistralContext

It would be very nice if custom actions could access to custom runtime execution context.
In some cases existing env is a good choice but sometimes if every execution needs
different context/env it could be a nightmare to manage env per execution or pass these
parameters down to each sub-workflow. Cloud authentication related context (MistralContext)
already addressed this issue, but it is not flexible enough.

Later may we need separate cloud credential from user_context.

Missing from current implementation:
- yaql function to reach user_context explicitly.

Change-Id: I517d6eb24b15dadb6ca402076a026e6abfbda637

commit_message:
Add oslo.i18n module in mistral project

1.Add oslo.i18n module.

2.Help messages and output info should support oslo.i18n.
  So we should use oslo.i18n in LOG.warning()/LOG.error()/
  LOG.info()/LOG.critical().

The more information as follow:
[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/usage.html

Change-Id: I535fe1af4e9d2afd06eb5900babae6ac48b6f48e
Partial-Implements: blueprint mistral-stadium-i18n

commit_message:
Replace test.attr with decorators.attr

Function 'tempest.test.attr()' has moved to 'tempest.lib.decorators
.attr()' in Pike and will be removed in a future version[1]. This patch
replaces the 'tempest.test.attr()' with the 'tempest.lib
.decorators.attr().'

Change-Id: I8679d1e568fecdcacfa6baed3fdd017149f5cd45

commit_message:
[WIP] Add pagination options for workflows and actions

The workflow and action output is missing pagination options like:
* marker
* limit
* sort-keys
* sort-dirs

These options are added in this patch.

Change-Id: I3cf594c0fb4e340abce0967980f56556c89da195
Implements: blueprint add-pagination

commit_message:
Support i18n for LOG.warning

log warning msg with _LW(), to
support i18n translation

Change-Id: I7958bfd5285a7f4f4448d420653661df7e19a114
Partial-Implements: blueprint mistral-i18n

[{'created': '2018-07-04 15:43:20.000000000', 'message': 'devstack: deploy openshift registry on origin envs

OpenShift functionality greatly depends on the openshift registry
being present. This patch ensures that once kuryr is running, it
will get deployed.

Change-Id: Idbaeb3b716dbbb689ebb01f92092f5302dc2c4f5
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <asegurap@redhat.com>

commit_message:
devstack: deploy openshift registry on origin envs

OpenShift functionality greatly depends on the openshift registry
being present. This patch ensures that once kuryr is running, it
will get deployed.

Change-Id: Idbaeb3b716dbbb689ebb01f92092f5302dc2c4f5
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <asegurap@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2017-05-17 11:37:38.000000000', 'message': 'Wrap token to auth plugin

Recently novaclient moved to keystoneauth. When a token is passed to it,
an instance of Token auth plugin is used to handle it. The problem with
it is that it tries to reauthenticate using the token. It is not
possible with trust-scoped token.

To avoid it we need to use an auth plugin that will not try to
re-authenticate, but rather use the existing token. After that,
the plugin needs to be passed with the session to novaclient.

Change-Id: Iaf3dc062ea7b8dce62e7be9ad2463375ab070a9a
Closes-Bug: 1690787
'}]
commit_message:
Wrap token to auth plugin

Recently novaclient moved to keystoneauth. When a token is passed to it,
an instance of Token auth plugin is used to handle it. The problem with
it is that it tries to reauthenticate using the token. It is not
possible with trust-scoped token.

To avoid it we need to use an auth plugin that will not try to
re-authenticate, but rather use the existing token. After that,
the plugin needs to be passed with the session to novaclient.

Change-Id: Iaf3dc062ea7b8dce62e7be9ad2463375ab070a9a
Closes-Bug: 1690787

commit_message:
Don't monkeypatch the executor

Running custom actions withint the eventlet code implies
serious limitations. Best option here is not to monkeypatch
the executor at all.

Change-Id: Iee65b69473f696c8502f90b76c8979403ec82a5e
Closes-Bug: #1728552

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-04-14 01:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-14 01:44:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

- gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/83/455083/2/check/gate-mistral-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial/0fc6499//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 58s
- gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/83/455083/2/check/gate-mistral-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/9c46d31/ : SUCCESS in 1m 45s'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-14 06:14:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I like the idea, we've been discussing it for long but never came up with a spec for it. So thanks for working on this.

Take a look at my comments please, a number of things are not clear to me now."}, {'account_id': 9029, 'date': '2017-04-14 19:36:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I like the idea as well.
Please also make the new service component optional and allow Mistral to work without it if needed.'}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-04-14 19:39:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

Renat, Thanks for reviewing/responding. Let's quickly exchange the design discussion here. I would like to close this soon."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2017-04-19 10:16:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

From my point of view, this is a use case of event trigger(maybe many people didn't even know we have this feature in mistral and I'm not sure if there is anyone using it). 

We just need to send notifications to MQ system and define the event trigger properly to execute the pre-defined workflow. In the workflow, you can do anything you want by invoking different actions (mistral defined or customized).

I don't see much more benefit of adding one more service dedicated for notification over a built-in feature in Mistral, unless we agree that that feature is not so useful in Mistral.

Just my 0.02"}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-04-19 18:27:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Renat, what do you think?'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-26 06:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-26 06:36:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-26 07:34:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Lingxian,

IMO, your idea looks interesting but.. Triggering workflows has the following downsides:

* We'll have a huge amount of workflow/task/action executions created only to deliver notifications to subscribers (imagine that we'll have a wf execution for each event of every workflow)
* Event triggers have the same problem as I described in my two previous replies (polling, delays, etc.)
* These special service workflows will go through the same execution mechanism (essentially engine) as regular workflows, therefore messages won't be often delivered for a long time just because how our current ordering works.
* It will reduce performance if normal user workflows

Given all that said, IMO, this needs to be a separate architectural component that don't clash with the rest of the system. And it could be optimized specifically for delivering notifications."}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2017-04-26 10:24:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I still prefer we don't recreate the wheels (just like the event trigger implementation) and not make the notification delivery mechanism too complex. If the event trigger is not a proper place for that purpose, why not just send notifications just like what other OpenStack services do? Leaving the rare case handled by 3rd party subscribers. If we don't trust anything and do everything inside Mistral, we will be more and more cumbersome."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-26 11:35:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Lingxian, what's so complex in sending messages over MQ and handling them by plugins? Other OpenStack services do a similar thing, don't they? Those plugins don't even have to be part of Mistral code base, btw. But I believe they are needed as a bridge to the outside world which is slightly special for Mistral comparing to other OpenStack projects. If you have other ideas, please do share them."}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2017-04-26 15:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2017-04-26 19:57:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Lingxian, what's so complex in sending messages over MQ and
 > handling them by plugins? Those plugins don't even have to be part of
 > Mistral code base

This is exactly what I mean,  I just don't like the idea that we store events inside Mistral database and send them by new plugins/services."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2017-04-27 04:34:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I just don't like the idea that we
 > store events inside Mistral database and send them by new
 > plugins/services.

No, I didn't meant that we need to store them. Just transfer them to handlers."}, {'account_id': 5558, 'date': '2017-05-24 23:29:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Renat, here's the draft/prototype of the implementation. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/467799/. Enabled per workflow execution, list of events can be configurable per workflow execution, type of notification whether it's via webhook or other 3rd party plugins are configured per workflow execution, events go to the MQ and process by the notification server which instantiates the plugin and invokes the notify method."}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-08-28 16:46:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-08-28 18:31:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16511, 'date': '2017-08-30 03:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-08-06 09:12:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning this patch per the Mistral Patch Abandonment guidelines
(https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/mistral-specs/specs/policy/patch-abandonment.html).
If you wish to have this restored and cannot do so yourself, please reach
out via #openstack-mistral on freenode or the OpenStack Dev mailing list.'}]

commit_message:
Add 'execution event publishing and subscription' spec

Allow 3rd party to subscribe to workflow execution events. Implement an event
notification service and instead of just publishing the events onto a message
queue (fire and forget), instantiate a 3rd party plugins to process and
publish the events and track whether the events have been successfully
processed. The plugin is intended to handle custom logic, processing,
endpoints, and authentication to the external system.

Change-Id: I8da6a359dff34cc86b63c5dbd77497573f6fdb66

commit_message:
update requirements for neutron-lib 1.18.0

Neutron-lib 1.18.0 is our Rocky RC and is already being used by neutron
[1]. This patch updates the neutron-lib required version to match
neutron [1] in prep for the Rocky release.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/583671/

Change-Id: I0186169cd9c531fff56f69c2a1f7d3306a7d19c6

commit_message:
Allow 400 response when creating kibana ES index

If the index already exists, kibana will respond with a 400 error. This
is required to support reconfigure and upgrade of kibana.

Change-Id: Ieee6d636fe81692dffb886f917b8398df10a525f

subject: Removes SG rules on port with SG disabled
messages: [{'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-08-02 13:05:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-08-02 14:21:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2018-08-06 08:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-02 13:05:03.000000000', 'message': "Removes SG rules on port with SG disabled

The SecurityGroupsDriver relies on its cache when removing a port's
ACL rules if the port's port_security_enabled field is False.

If the port was updated while the agent was down, the cache will be
empty, and thus skip removing the port's ACLs.

This patch addresses this issue by removing all of the port's ACLs if
the port's port_security_enabled is False.

Change-Id: Ibda80fbd17310e13ceb7fe4e6db7f68e6403e87b
Closes-Bug: #1747666
(cherry picked from commit 13a1d75fe79dc05c7822625b29fe07554855d70e)
"}]
commit_message:
Removes SG rules on port with SG disabled

The SecurityGroupsDriver relies on its cache when removing a port's
ACL rules if the port's port_security_enabled field is False.

If the port was updated while the agent was down, the cache will be
empty, and thus skip removing the port's ACLs.

This patch addresses this issue by removing all of the port's ACLs if
the port's port_security_enabled is False.

Change-Id: Ibda80fbd17310e13ceb7fe4e6db7f68e6403e87b
Closes-Bug: #1747666
(cherry picked from commit 13a1d75fe79dc05c7822625b29fe07554855d70e)

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch to stestr as other projects have already moved to it.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I5f4b45587b63c6132ac974eb65f7fd83b62ef1a8

subject: Add custom-context-for-executions spec
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7065, 'name': 'Brad P. Crochet', 'email': 'brad@redhat.com', 'username': 'bcrochet'}, {'_account_id': 8731, 'name': 'Renat Akhmerov', 'email': 'renat.akhmerov@gmail.com', 'username': 'rakhmerov'}, {'_account_id': 9712, 'name': 'Dougal Matthews', 'email': 'dougal.matthews@canonical.com', 'username': 'dougal'}, {'_account_id': 11085, 'name': 'Toure Dunnon', 'email': 'toure@redhat.com', 'username': 'Toure'}, {'_account_id': 15895, 'name': 'Adriano Petrich', 'email': 'apetrich@redhat.com', 'username': 'apetrich'}, {'_account_id': 21970, 'name': 'Andras Kovi', 'email': 'akovi@nokia.com', 'username': 'andras.kovi'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-07-26 17:18:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-30 09:07:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

Generally looks good to me. I agree with the idea.

I'm just thinking if we can relate it somehow with workflow environment concept that we already have. I understand it's a little different but may be we at least need to clearly separate these two things in the spec and make it clear how they will co-exist.

Also, we now have SecurityContext (mentioned in the spec) and ExecutionContext classes defined in mistral-lib. How do you see their further fate? One option is to generalize everything under one class and another one is to leave those two as they are. I don't have a clear vision yet.. Just some thoughts."}, {'account_id': 21970, 'date': '2018-07-30 15:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > Generally looks good to me. I agree with the idea.
 > 
 > I'm just thinking if we can relate it somehow with workflow
 > environment concept that we already have. I understand it's a
 > little different but may be we at least need to clearly separate
 > these two things in the spec and make it clear how they will
 > co-exist.
 > 
 > Also, we now have SecurityContext (mentioned in the spec) and
 > ExecutionContext classes defined in mistral-lib. How do you see
 > their further fate? One option is to generalize everything under
 > one class and another one is to leave those two as they are. I
 > don't have a clear vision yet.. Just some thoughts.

I'm not sure the environment can be reused in this case. The env is reusable, it is created offline and generally should be used to convey parameters pertaining to the given workflow. The context parameters, in my opinion, are lower level and required for the correct operation of actions.

To simplify things, contrary to this spec, I wouldn't put the new data under a special key. I'd just state that the usual scheme for adding new data is to use a main key and put everything under that. This way the 'security' can remain the OS auth, the 'execution' can remain the Mistral specific data, and it is possible to extend the remaining in whatever ways desired. I don't think that we should go further down the road on the specialization and rigidization of the context.

So I think we should leave the SecCont and ExecCont as they are and allow to extend the rest of the context in arbitrary ways.

FYI: Another extension we may need is the updating of the context. E.g. when the OS token expires, we need a way to update it with a new one. Currently, even if we obtained a new one, the context on the action side is immutable, so this cannot be implemented."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-07-31 04:06:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Ok, I agree with that. Thanks Andras. Giving +2 and hoping to get 2 more +2s since this is a spec and touches an important aspect of the system.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2018-08-03 11:41:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2018-08-06 08:38:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-26 17:18:45.000000000', 'message': 'Add custom-context-for-executions spec

Extend the context with custom parameters to make it
generally available for custom actions and support
the separation of OpenStack actions from the core.

Change-Id: If5ea987f3d9d70c288b12f549434f9e8d6853c66
'}]
commit_message:
Add custom-context-for-executions spec

Extend the context with custom parameters to make it
generally available for custom actions and support
the separation of OpenStack actions from the core.

Change-Id: If5ea987f3d9d70c288b12f549434f9e8d6853c66

commit_message:
Deprecate upgrade_levels options for deprecated/removed services

* nova-cert was removed in Pike: 2bcee77e3

* nova-network has been deprecated since newton: 7d5fc4868

* nova-consoleauth was deprecated in rocky: e91dad3ee

So start the timer on the related upgrade_levels options
so we can remove them.

Change-Id: Ied416335d36fe3324fb1c5c78353affe1332ba90

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-20282 : FAILURE in 1h 23m 59s'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-06-19 09:04:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Eric, if you look at the bug you will see that the method time too 10.666 seconds. After the change it took less than a second.
It is still unclear to me why the deepcopy was done.'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-06-19 09:05:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

018-06-17 10:30:56.194 1658 DEBUG oslo_concurrency.lockutils [req-fb2573f9-3862-45db-b546-7a00fdd9a871 - - - - -] Lock "compute_resources" released by "nova.compute.resource_tracker._update_available_resource" :: held 10.666s inner /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/oslo_concurrency/lockutils.py:288

in the bug report'}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-06-19 09:13:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-06-19 14:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with check hyper-v

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com//nova/576099/2/ : FAILURE in 2h 31m 49s'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-19 17:15:25.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from deepcopy to bug/1777422'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-19 17:29:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I took a closer look at this, and although I have no evidence that the deepcopy is necessary, I also haven't convinced myself that it's completely *un*necessary, especially in the ironic case.

However, I am convinced that we don't need to do it once per instance.  I proposed an alternative [1] which keeps the deepcopy, but runs it only once per compute node per periodic.  Would you mind trying it out in your environment to see if you get similar performance improvements?

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/576591/"}, {'account_id': 6062, 'date': '2018-06-20 05:21:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

@Eric, and seems the new one proposed doesn't work? maybe still need some fix within this patch?"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-06-20 08:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Eric, I tried your patch and added comments there. It did not work. The idea looks like it is in the right direction.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-28 20:28:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-06-28 20:30:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-06-28 21:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-07-02 17:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 14:28:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think we should ease into this and do as I suggested by moving the stats deepcopy out of the per-instance method and do the copy at the end after we've processed all instances. If that is still not good enough, we can see if removing the deepcopy helps enough."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 14:35:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-07-31 15:59:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Matt, I *think* that's what I was trying to do with [1], but I couldn't get it to work. If you can, power to ya.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/576591/"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 17:41:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 18:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 19:21:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I wrote a functional scale test to try and compare the before and after for this change:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587606/

but at the current scale it's probably too variable to be reliable."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 22:12:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/587636/ this also fixes your deepcopy issue while not breaking (actually it fixes) ironic.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-31 22:12:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2018-08-06 06:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Addressed by Matts changes. Still have not yet had time to validate those in a performance env.'}]

commit_message:
Resource tracker: remove costly copy

In the resource tracker periodic task the code does a deepcopy
for the stats. This is very costly and copies the structure N times
(where N is the amount of running instances on the host).

Change-Id: I53940d8dd3735dec1cf1d0bdae2216ff42853ba2
Closes-bug: #1777422

commit_message:
Clarify what an exception from an action means

When Python actions raise an exception they may not have failed to run.
This may not even be an issue. For example, the OpenStack action
`swift.head_container` will raise an exception is the container doesn't
exist.

This change lowers the exception to a warning but keeps the exception
traceback in the logs. It also changes the wording in the message. We
didn't fail to run the action, rather the action raise an exception.

Change-Id: If9a6a3b98999acae8b80ad4ddeb9d197a628c280

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 11:46:01.000000000', 'message': 'Add "start_version" and "end_version" support to  argparse

Now, "manila help subcommand" can not show whether an argument
is supported for a specific microversion.
With this change, developers only need to add a start_version or
end_version in the utils.arg wrap, manilaclient will support
the microversion for that arguement.

    @utils.arg(
    '--foo',
    start_version='3.1')
    @utils.arg(
    '--bar',
    start_version='3.2',
    end_version='3.5')
    def do_some_action():
        ......

This patch borrows the same logic from cinderclient [1] and
setups the basic framework for this addition. Following
patches can upgrade the commands to use these options.

[1]: b76f5944130e29ee1bf3095c966a393c489c05e6

Change-Id: Iae12f5f4e977d98d64666cc3e7b307eabbbd64c8

commit_message:
Add "start_version" and "end_version" support to  argparse

Now, "manila help subcommand" can not show whether an argument
is supported for a specific microversion.
With this change, developers only need to add a start_version or
end_version in the utils.arg wrap, manilaclient will support
the microversion for that arguement.

    @utils.arg(
    '--foo',
    start_version='3.1')
    @utils.arg(
    '--bar',
    start_version='3.2',
    end_version='3.5')
    def do_some_action():
        ......

This patch borrows the same logic from cinderclient [1] and
setups the basic framework for this addition. Following
patches can upgrade the commands to use these options.

[1]: b76f5944130e29ee1bf3095c966a393c489c05e6

Change-Id: Iae12f5f4e977d98d64666cc3e7b307eabbbd64c8

commit_message:
Avoid server_check_teardown exception breaking tearDown

server_check_teardown will raise Exception which will prevent
other cleanup steps from being executed(i.e., those added with
addCleanup), so server_check_teardown should be called after
super's tearDown.

Change-Id: I1060e2ccdb1ef8ae1e8f1f682fc5d115d129c3ca

[{'created': '2018-08-02 22:39:59.000000000', 'message': "Add route when required on the local table

With the use of nspawn containers and macvlans, without an intermediary
bridge, there's no way to send traffic from the host back to the
container without configuring VEPA and having 802.1qg enabled
switches. To enhance the usability of nspawn a local route is added to
macvlan devices when an interface address is detected. This allows
the host to route back to the containers without issues and will not

commit_message:
Add route when required on the local table

With the use of nspawn containers and macvlans, without an intermediary
bridge, there's no way to send traffic from the host back to the
container without configuring VEPA and having 802.1qg enabled
switches. To enhance the usability of nspawn a local route is added to
macvlan devices when an interface address is detected. This allows
the host to route back to the containers without issues and will not
interfere with the main host route. To ensure there's absolutely no
conflict with host routes a metric has added to all routes added to the
local table.

Change-Id: Id4326c9783f46884d3f39692e691775ba1118b38
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fix the create/delete instance error using nova cell with tricircle

1. What is the problem?

   in nova cell with tricircle, instances can not be create and delete sucessful

2. What is the solution to the problem?

   fix the error in creaton and deletion of tricircle

3. What the features to be implemented in the Tricircle to realize the solution?

   no

<Co-Authored-By: tangzhuo <ztang@hnu.edu.cn>>
Change-Id: If1ffdb245f0c03e11d0273b5e238c93c3f23bc8b

Code optimization of create application credential

We check if user has specified roles in project when creating
application credential. The code can be optimized here instead
of two level loop.

commit_message:
Unpin ceph-ansible and add ceph-ansible library path

The ceph-ansible project has created a new library which
is held in the root folder. We need to ensure that the
library path is included.

Additionally, a callback plugins directory exists within ceph-ansible
that we should also import.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/587198
Change-Id: Ic70d0e9eb57be9a9a1d8a658ceacc50c47ab9c02
Co-Authored-By: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
(cherry picked from commit 8c8e4beda733648946140a5a14d23a346d3b5292)

commit_message:
Update the default admission control list

The recommended admission controller list is:
NamespaceLifecycle,LimitRanger,ServiceAccount,DefaultStorageClass,
DefaultTolerationSeconds,MutatingAdmissionWebhook,
ValidatingAdmissionWebhook,ResourceQuota

[0] https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/access-authn-authz/admission-controllers/#is-there-a-recommended-set-of-admission-controllers-to-use

Change-Id: I663804d93d5ff8dc70171bcd7d61b2d92c8616e1

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: I061b2e278b9eaacb632459e1dc9e1de54b1be13f
Co-Authored-By: Nguyen Hai <nguyentrihai93@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-01 08:38:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix VIM register API 500 error issue

If user passes non-dict or empty dict to the auth_cred and
vim_project parameters, then tacker returns 500 error.

This patch fixes the issue by adding a new validator type
"dict_not_empty" and using at the required places. Now, if
users passes non-dict or empty dict to VIM Register API,
then it will return 400(BadRequest) error.

Change-Id: Ic144df6af606286ed3eea7f7071f061bceffaa7f
'}]
commit_message:
Fix VIM register API 500 error issue

If user passes non-dict or empty dict to the auth_cred and
vim_project parameters, then tacker returns 500 error.

This patch fixes the issue by adding a new validator type
"dict_not_empty" and using at the required places. Now, if
users passes non-dict or empty dict to VIM Register API,
then it will return 400(BadRequest) error.

Change-Id: Ic144df6af606286ed3eea7f7071f061bceffaa7f

commit_message:
devstack check neutron-qos available

check neutron-qos available before adding neutron_qos data source
to Congress. Avoids the data source update errors arising from
adding the data source when the qos extension is not available.

Release-team: devstack plugin change only

Change-Id: Ie5b10b20f11f109bb7159d43a0f5303508b00f78

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

commit_message:
Pass microversion info through from Profile

Even though Profile is going away, senlinclient is still using it.
There is a patch up to fix that, but in the meantime, let's fix it for
their issue. api_version in Profile is the variable for setting a
default microversion, but the translation method didn't set it.

Story: 2003146
Change-Id: I6efd25959127bbe28e76b1967caa5b3716346c7e

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of moving
the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each project
repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I1db6b56d7c7e1cce9f681ef51d76f3af103431bf
Story: #2003250

[{'created': '2018-07-31 06:15:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix error about kibana restart failed

Because kibana has no permission to create "/opt/kibana/bin".
Use symlink to run kibana on RPM-based distro is not good.
In order to run different kibana executable file on different distro,
we can create a parameter named "kolla_default_executable" to solve it.

Change-Id: I963bb0622cdeea3966f3fe682a5cbd733cc5c108
Signed-off-by: pengdake <19921207pq@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-07-31 06:17:47.000000000', 'message': 'Fix error about kibana restart failed

Because kibana has no permission to create "/opt/kibana/bin".
Use symlink to run kibana on RPM-based distro is not good.
In order to run different kibana executable file on different distro,
we can create a parameter named "kolla_default_executable" to solve it.

Close-Bugs: #1784546

Change-Id: I963bb0622cdeea3966f3fe682a5cbd733cc5c108
Signed-off-by: pengdake <19921207pq@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix error about kibana restart failed

Because kibana has no permission to create "/opt/kibana/bin".
Use symlink to run kibana on RPM-based distro is not good.
In order to run different kibana executable file on different distro,
we can create a parameter named "kolla_default_executable" to solve it.

Close-Bugs: #1784546

Change-Id: I963bb0622cdeea3966f3fe682a5cbd733cc5c108
Signed-off-by: pengdake <19921207pq@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Enforce channel modes with accessbot

In the dependent change, accessbot gains the ability to set channel
modes.  Enforce our global mode of registered users only, with a
forward to #openstack-unregistered to catch those who need help with
nickserv.

Change-Id: I004f7c9c9093262bea6e841be41166d3b6ecfb10
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/588134

subject: Add python3 django 1.11 job instead of django 2.0 job
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-08-04 13:19:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2018-08-06 00:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-04 13:19:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add python3 django 1.11 job instead of django 2.0 job

Django 2.0 is now used in tox py35 job, so there is no need for
py35dj20 job. Instead, Django 1.11 with python3 is not covered.

- py35dj20 job is dropped from tox.ini.
- python3-django111 is added to tox.ini.
  python3 is specified to basepython to avoid a specific python version.
- .zuul.yaml is updated to consume horizon-openstack-tox-python3-django111
  and drop horizon-openstack-tox-py35dj20.

Change-Id: Ib93224c3f261d52499c0e4900bb32da907eb69bd
'}]
commit_message:
Add python3 django 1.11 job instead of django 2.0 job

Django 2.0 is now used in tox py35 job, so there is no need for
py35dj20 job. Instead, Django 1.11 with python3 is not covered.

- py35dj20 job is dropped from tox.ini.
- python3-django111 is added to tox.ini.
  python3 is specified to basepython to avoid a specific python version.
- .zuul.yaml is updated to consume horizon-openstack-tox-python3-django111
  and drop horizon-openstack-tox-py35dj20.

Change-Id: Ib93224c3f261d52499c0e4900bb32da907eb69bd

commit_message:
import zuul job settings from project-config

This is a mostly mechanically generated patch to complete step 1 of
moving the zuul job settings out of project-config and into each
project repository.

Because there will be a separate patch on each branch, the branch
specifiers for branch-specific jobs have been removed.

The legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-zmq job is only used by this plugin, so
we move the playbook and job definition here as well. It needs to be
renamed in order to be moved and applied to the repository, so the new
name devstack-plugin-zmq-tempest-full is used to indicate that it is
defined within the repository.

See the python3-first goal document for details:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/stein/python3-first.html

Change-Id: I3d80c8a576fa4cbedffdaaf6cf97a4a61a2dce34
Story: #2003250

The ceph-ansible project has created a new library which
is held in the root folder. We need to ensure that the
library path is included.

Additionally a callback plugins directory inside plugins/callback has
been added, along with an action plugins directory inside
plugins/actions.

Finally, the sed command we use to replace the default roles directory
was causing issues in that it applied to any lines that were not
necessarily the roles_path. This PR adjusts the sed to ensure it is only
the roles_path line that is replaced.

Change-Id: I0d30d749ef2e00c1d199e53a837462619a9b2650
(cherry picked from commit 0943a630bb303d9badf9edfdcc466abf1c211304)
'}]
commit_message:
Add ceph-ansible library and callback path

The ceph-ansible project has created a new library which
is held in the root folder. We need to ensure that the
library path is included.

Additionally a callback plugins directory inside plugins/callback has
been added, along with an action plugins directory inside
plugins/actions.

Finally, the sed command we use to replace the default roles directory
was causing issues in that it applied to any lines that were not
necessarily the roles_path. This PR adjusts the sed to ensure it is only
the roles_path line that is replaced.

Change-Id: I0d30d749ef2e00c1d199e53a837462619a9b2650
(cherry picked from commit 0943a630bb303d9badf9edfdcc466abf1c211304)

[{'created': '2018-07-22 16:38:31.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I5bef9cf872f0d515c1bdfedb157febf6a0194362
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I5bef9cf872f0d515c1bdfedb157febf6a0194362

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I30bc962aacc4e6b12835b36c6bd074ae0c988b04

[{'created': '2018-08-01 04:12:38.000000000', 'message': "Fix repeat ID problem in library policy display

In library policy dashboard, sometimes the same rule is
repeated multiple times, overwriting some subsequent rules.
For example, in Policy Details: TagBasedNetworkSecurityZone,
the first two rules displays as

security_zone_tags('demo_zone'),
security_zone_tags('demo_zone')

rather than the correct

security_zone_tags('demo_zone'),
security_zone_tags('production_zone').

This patch fixes the issue by making sure a distinct ID is
assigned to each rule for django.

Change-Id: I20d758ec4dffeaecf60f6c60c401bb08e359def5
Closes-Bug: 1784770
"}]
commit_message:
Fix repeat ID problem in library policy display

In library policy dashboard, sometimes the same rule is
repeated multiple times, overwriting some subsequent rules.
For example, in Policy Details: TagBasedNetworkSecurityZone,
the first two rules displays as

security_zone_tags('demo_zone'),
security_zone_tags('demo_zone')

rather than the correct

security_zone_tags('demo_zone'),
security_zone_tags('production_zone').

This patch fixes the issue by making sure a distinct ID is
assigned to each rule for django.

Change-Id: I20d758ec4dffeaecf60f6c60c401bb08e359def5
Closes-Bug: 1784770

commit_message:
Z3 as an alternative Datalog engine

Z3 is an open source automatic theorem prover developed by Microsoft.
This spec describes how to add Z3 as an alternative Datalog engine
in Congress.

Change-Id: Ie1e891408c3f03618926cff4d88e7904b0c0e370

commit_message:
Deprecate of_interface for ovs

The parameter of_interface was use for OpenFlow
interfaces. This parameter is deprecated in neutron
project so it can be deprecated also in puppet.

Change-Id: Ic866355e7d24bff5885e3b894c97fe6cf3c174f9
Closes-Bug: 1734241

commit_message:
FloatingIPQosTest: Stop inheriting QoSTest class

Instead, have a separate class for shared code (QoSTestMixin)
so that we can add test cases to QoSTest without affecting
FloatingIPQosTest.

Change-Id: I2fc2d2a94e78298c2bded00b585c8a1ae852fc0a

commit_message:
Fix mmultiple argument passing

Now allow to pass extra arguments to ansible-playbook like -v[v[v]] or others
This also factorizes indentical code for better readbility

Change-Id: I55a9e308dd1f8227fba32338827a289587251b39

commit_message:

This PS updates the keysteone endpoints section used in the
webhook authenticator and the prometheus exporter.
